verses.text: David spoke the words of this song to the LORD on the day when the LORD delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
verses.comment: This song is parallel to Psalm 18 and expresses David's gratitude for God's deliverance. It marks a historical turning point in David's life, after enduring many persecutions.

verses.text: He said, 'The LORD is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer.'
verses.comment: God is described using images of strength and protection, anticipating Christ as the ultimate foundation and defender of his people. See also Matthew 7:24, where Jesus uses the rock metaphor.

verses.text: 'My God, my rock, in whom I take refuge, my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my stronghold and my refuge, my savior; you save me from violence.'
verses.comment: David lists God's attributes with repetition, emphasizing total dependence on God. 'Horn of salvation' is later applied to Christ (Luke 1:69).

verses.text: 'I call upon the LORD, who is worthy to be praised, and I am saved from my enemies.'
verses.comment: Prayer and praise are linked in David's song, showing the power of invoking God's name in faith for deliverance.

verses.text: 'For the waves of death surrounded me; the floods of destruction overwhelmed me.'
verses.comment: David uses poetic imagery to describe mortal danger, echoing later Psalms and foreshadowing the sufferings of Christ.

verses.text: 'The cords of Sheol entangled me; the snares of death confronted me.'
verses.comment: References to Sheol express near hopelessness, but God is able to rescue from the deep, as he later does through Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: 'In my distress I called upon the LORD; to my God I cried. From his temple he heard my voice, and my cry came to his ears.'
verses.comment: The temple theme points to the centrality of worship and God's responsiveness to prayer. Spiritual interpretation recognizes this as a call for believers to pray efficiently and trust God's listening.

verses.text: 'Then the earth shook and trembled; the foundations of heaven quaked because he was angry.'
verses.comment: God’s power over creation is highlighted using earthquake imagery. Similar language is found at Sinai, and later at Jesus’ crucifixion (Matthew 27:51).

verses.text: 'Smoke went up from his nostrils, and devouring fire from his mouth; glowing coals blazed forth from him.'
verses.comment: Anthropomorphic language depicts God’s wrath as fire, reminiscent of Sinai and the glory manifest at Pentecost (Acts 2:3).

verses.text: 'He bowed the heavens and came down; thick darkness was under his feet.'
verses.comment: God’s majestic descent echoes the cloud and darkness at Sinai and prefigures later divine theophanies.

verses.text: 'He rode on a cherub and flew; he was seen on the wings of the wind.'
verses.comment: Cherubim imagery indicates divine authority over angels; wind heralds God’s spirit and power moving throughout creation.

verses.text: 'He made darkness coverings around him, thick clouds, gathering water.'
verses.comment: God’s mysterious presence is described poetically as clouds and darkness, which also symbolize impending judgment and the hiddenness of God.

verses.text: 'Out of the brightness before him, coals of fire flamed forth.'
verses.comment: The brightness suggests God’s glory, the coals of fire his purifying judgment, both seen at Sinai and Pentecost.

verses.text: 'The LORD thundered from heaven, and the Most High uttered his voice.'
verses.comment: Thunder is a sign of God’s power; voice and thunder combine at Sinai and Jesus’ baptism (John 12:28-29).

verses.text: 'He sent out arrows and scattered them, lightning, and routed them.'
verses.comment: Arrows and lightning refer to divine judgment, as God’s intervention scatters enemies.

verses.text: 'Then the channels of the sea were seen; the foundations of the world were uncovered at the rebuke of the LORD, at the blast of the breath of his nostrils.'
verses.comment: Miraculous parting of waters recalls the Exodus. Breath of God’s nostrils indicates power in speaking and presence.

verses.text: 'He reached down from on high, he took me; he drew me out of deep waters.'
verses.comment: Rescue is personal and direct, anticipating God’s intervention for all believers, with spiritual baptismal implications.

verses.text: 'He rescued me from my strong enemy, from those who hated me, for they were too mighty for me.'
verses.comment: Emphasis on human weakness and the necessity of trusting God.

verses.text: 'They confronted me in the day of my calamity, but the LORD was my support.'
verses.comment: Theme of divine support in times of trouble is central to David’s experience, anticipating Christ’s victory in despair.

verses.text: 'He brought me out into a broad place; he rescued me because he delighted in me.'
verses.comment: 'Broad place' implies freedom and a new creation. Divine delight prefigures Jesus as the beloved Son (Matthew 3:17).

verses.text: 'The LORD dealt with me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands he rewarded me.'
verses.comment: Righteousness and clean hands suggest moral purity before God, a theme that points forward to the new covenant.

verses.text: 'For I have kept the ways of the LORD and have not wickedly departed from my God.'
verses.comment: This verse might overstate David’s perfection, but in context refers to covenant fidelity, not absolute moral sinlessness.

verses.text: 'For all his judgments were before me, and I did not turn aside from his statutes.'
verses.comment: David honors God’s law, which is a continuing theme throughout salvation history and a model for Christian obedience.

verses.text: 'I was blameless before him, and I kept myself from guilt.'
verses.comment: A statement of integrity in relationship with God, not absolute perfection. Connects back to Noah and later saints.

verses.text: 'So the LORD rewarded me according to my righteousness, according to the cleanness of my hands in his sight.'
verses.comment: Divine reward ties to righteousness, reflecting enduring biblical principles later affirmed by Christ.

verses.text: 'With the faithful you show yourself faithful; with the blameless man you show yourself blameless.'
verses.comment: God’s justice is reciprocal, rewarding those who mirror divine attributes. Spiritual interpretation invites believers to virtue.

verses.text: 'With the pure you show yourself pure, and with the crooked you show yourself shrewd.'
verses.comment: Purity and divine shrewdness highlight both God’s mercy and justice, anticipating Jesus’ teachings on parables.

verses.text: 'You save a humble people, but your eyes are against the proud— you abase them.'
verses.comment: God’s preference for humility over pride is a consistent theme, later emphasized by Jesus in the Sermon on the Mount.

verses.text: 'You are my lamp, O LORD; my God lightens my darkness.'
verses.comment: Light as a metaphor for divine revelation and guidance prefigures Christ’s claim as the “Light of the World.”

verses.text: 'For by you I can run against a troop, and by my God I can leap over a wall.'
verses.comment: Hyperbolic language for divine empowerment, emphasizing God’s ability to strengthen his chosen ones for impossible tasks.

verses.text: 'This God—his way is perfect; the word of the LORD is tested; he is a shield for all who take refuge in him.'
verses.comment: God’s word is likened to refined metal—without flaw. Taking refuge is both an act of trust and spiritual allegiance.

verses.text: 'For who is God besides the LORD? And who is a rock except our God?'
verses.comment: Foundational assertion of monotheism, with rock imagery leading to a deeper understanding of God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: 'God is my strong refuge and makes my way blameless.'
verses.comment: God sanctifies and guides, preparing those who trust in him to walk uprightly.

verses.text: 'He makes my feet like those of a deer and sets me secure on the heights.'
verses.comment: The feet of a deer symbolize agility and stability, metaphorically representing spiritual progress toward God.

verses.text: 'He trains my hands for battle, so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.'
verses.comment: Divine training empowers believers for their vocations, both in spiritual and earthly battles.

verses.text: 'You have given me the shield of your salvation, and your gentleness has made me great.'
verses.comment: Salvation as a shield is echoed in Ephesians 6:16; God’s gentleness is transformative, not just overpowering.

verses.text: 'You enlarged my steps under me, and my feet did not slip.'
verses.comment: Stability in life is a result of God’s constant preservation.

verses.text: 'I pursued my enemies and destroyed them. I did not turn back until they were consumed.'
verses.comment: Victory here is absolute, underscoring the completeness of deliverance afforded to David, figuratively to all in Christ.

verses.text: 'I consumed them and crushed them, so that they could not rise; they fell under my feet.'
verses.comment: The enemy defeated underfoot links to Christ putting all enemies under his feet at the resurrection.

verses.text: 'For you equipped me with strength for battle; you made those who rose against me fall under me.'
verses.comment: God’s enabling power brings victory, both physically for David and spiritually for the believer.

verses.text: 'You made my enemies turn their backs to me, those who hated me, I destroyed.'
verses.comment: God’s intervention reverses the opposition, demonstrating divine justice.

verses.text: 'They looked, but there was none to save; to the LORD, but he did not answer them.'
verses.comment: Only those who seek God in faith will find salvation; divine silence is the consequence of rejecting God.

verses.text: 'I beat them as fine as the dust of the earth; I crushed them and stamped them down like the dirt in the streets.'
verses.comment: Judgment is complete and humiliating for the enemies, emphasizing the thoroughness of God’s victory through his servant.

verses.text: 'You delivered me from the strife of my people; you kept me as the head of nations; people whom I had not known served me.'
verses.comment: International recognition forecasts the messianic reign in which the nations serve the chosen king. Spiritual meaning points to unity under the headship of Christ.

verses.text: 'Foreigners came cringing to me; as soon as they heard, they obeyed me.'
verses.comment: Submission of outsiders emphasizes God’s plan for universal sovereignty and the authority of his appointed ruler.

verses.text: 'Foreigners lost heart and came trembling out of their strongholds.'
verses.comment: Fear and trembling before God's chosen king forecasts the final authority of Christ at the end of the age.

verses.text: 'The LORD lives, and blessed be my rock, and exalted be my God, the rock of my salvation,'
verses.comment: The living God is distinct from lifeless idols. This affirmation, repeated in worship, points to the centrality of faith in the one true foundation.

verses.text: 'The God who gave me vengeance and subdued peoples under me,'
verses.comment: God is portrayed as active in justice and kingly victory.

verses.text: 'Who brought me out from my enemies; you exalted me above those who rose against me; you delivered me from violent men.'
verses.comment: Physical deliverance prefigures spiritual salvation offered to believers.

verses.text: 'Therefore I will give thanks to you, O LORD, among the nations, and sing praises to your name.'
verses.comment: Thanksgiving among the nations anticipates the global scope of redemption, cited by Paul regarding the extension of salvation to Gentiles.

verses.text: 'Great salvation he brings to his king, and shows steadfast love to his anointed, to David and his offspring forever.'
verses.comment: This closing verse speaks directly to God’s covenant faithfulness, prefiguring the eternal dynasty fulfilled in Jesus, David’s son and eternal king. The phrase 'his anointed' (Hebrew 'Messiah') points toward the universal blessing and the enduring promise to David’s line.
